_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Helena Chemical Company (HCC) Central Ferry Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the temporary storage of anhydrous ammonia Railcars at this facility, and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The RMPr includes all Program 2 Accident Prevention Program elements: Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response.  



Covered Process 1 (i.e. Railcar Storage ? Anhydrous Ammonia) equipment includes 34,000-gallon railcars.  A typical railcar shipment includes 10 to 15 railcars.  However, the maximum number of anhydrous ammonia railcars that have been temporarily stored at the Facility is 20.  Therefore, HCC is reporting its maximum quantity to be 20 anhydrous ammonia railcars.  



HCC does not own the railcars and therefore is not responsible for the mechanical integrity of the railcar.  However, trained HCC personnel receive, inspect, and release railcars in accordance with its RMPr Railcar Operating Procedures.  HCC is responsible for training its personnel in the Railcar Operating Procedures.  Transfer of anhydrous ammonia from the railcars to Covered Processes 3, 5, and 7 is addressed under those specific covered processes.

_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Integrating railcar operating procedures into the Facility inspection and documentation of aqua railcars.
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Helena Chemical Company (HCC) Central Ferry Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the temporary storage of aqua ammonia (29% Nitrogen) Railcars at this facility, and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The RMPr includes all Program 2 Accident Prevention Program elements: Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response.  



Covered Process 2 (i.e. Railcar Storage ? Aqua Ammonia) equipment includes 22,000-gallon railcars of 29% Nitrogen.  The maximum number of aqua ammonia railcars that have been temporarily stored at the Facility is 9.  Therefore, HCC is reporting its maximum quantity to be 9 aqua ammonia railcars.  



HCC does not own the railcars and therefore is not responsible for the mechanical integrity of the railcar.  However, trained HCC personnel receive, inspect, and release railcars in accordance with its RMPr Railcar Operating Procedures.  HCC is responsible for training its personnel in the Railcar Operating Procedures.  Transfer of aqua ammonia from the railcars to Covered Processes 4 and 6 is addressed under those specific covered processes.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Transfer hose, vapor compressor and motor, valves
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Helena Chemical Company (HCC) Central Ferry Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained HCC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Covered Process 3 (i.e. Anhydrous Ammonia Transfer to Tanker Trucks) equipment includes a single 34,000-gallon anhydrous ammonia railcar, railcar nipple adaptors, transfer hoses, valves, and a vapor compressor.  From the railcars, the anhydrous ammonia is transferred into Commercial Tanker Trucks (Tanker Trucks) for transportation to the client location.  There are two Tanker Truck Load-Out Stations (North and South) but only one Tanker Truck can be loaded at a time as there is only one vapor compressor.  



Trained HCC personnel perform the transfer of anhydrous ammonia into the Tanker Trucks in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Storage and Handling Operating Procedures.  Trained HCC personnel perform the maintenance on this covered process in accordance with its PSM/RMPr Mechanical Integrity Procedures.  HCC is responsible for training its personnel in these Operating and Maintenance Procedures.

_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Process piping, transfer hoses, liquid pump and motor, flow meter, and valves
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Helena Chemical Company (HCC) Central Ferry Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the transfer of aqua ammonia (29% Nitrogen) from Railcars at this facility, and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The RMPr includes all Program 2 Accident Prevention Program elements: Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response.



Covered Process 4 (i.e. Aqua Ammonia Transfer to Storage Tanks) equipment includes a single 20,000-gallon aqua ammonia railcar, an emergency shutoff valve, transfer hoses, process piping, liquid pump and motor, flow meter (i.e. to measure flow and specific gravity) and valves.  As the Process Operators transfer the 29% aqua ammonia from the railcar, they mix water at the manifold during the transfer process and reduce the Nitrogen to 20% or less.  The Process Operator is able to determine the amount of water for mixing by monitoring the specific gravity at the flow meter.  The aqua ammonia (20% Nitrogen) is pumped to the five (5) aboveground storage tanks (AST) that are part of Covered Process 6 (Storage and Handling ? Aqua Ammonia).  



Trained Process Operators transfer the aqua ammonia from the railcar to the ASTs in accordance with its RMPr Operating Procedures.  Trained HCC personnel perform the maintenance on this covered process in accordance with its PSM/RMPr Mechanical Integrity Procedures.  HCC is responsible for training its personnel in these Operating and Maintenance Procedures.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Installation of process control valve - solenoid
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: transfer hoses, risers, valves, process piping, blenders
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Helena Chemical Company (HCC) Central Ferry Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained HCC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Covered Process 5 (i.e. Aqua Ammonium Blending) equipment includes one (1) or two (2) 34,000-gallon railcars, three Risers (i.e. 1, 2 and 2B), railcar nipple adaptors, transfer hoses, process piping, valves, and two Blenders (Aqua Blenders 1 and 2).  The Blenders are physically connected by process piping and transfer hoses to the railcar when in operation.  The anhydrous ammonia is transferred to the Blenders by the pressure in the railcars.  With the exception of the railcars, the aqua ammonium blending equipment is owned and operated by HCC.  The aqua ammonia blenders do not have any storage capabilities for anhydrous ammonia.  Aqua-ammonia is a fertilizer that is manufactured by blending anhydrous ammonia and water in a ?stationary blender? (i.e. Aqua Ammonia Blending) to make a solution that is up to 20% aqua ammonia by weight.  After blending, the aqua ammonia product is transferred by piping to one of the five aboveground storage tanks.  



Trained Process Operators perform the transfer of anhydrous ammonia to the aqua ammonia blenders, operate the aqua ammonia blenders, and then transfer the aqua ammonia to storage in accordance with its PSM/RMPr Operating Procedures.  Trained HCC personnel perform the maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Mechanical Integrity Procedures.  HCC is responsible for training its personnel in the Operating and Maintenance Procedures.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Helena Chemical Company (HCC) Central Ferry Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained HCC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Covered Process 6 (i.e. Storage and Handling ? Aqua Ammonia) equipment includes five (5) aboveground storage tanks (AST) and ancillary pumps, process piping, flow meters, valves, and transfer hoses.  The ASTs include one 36,000-gallon, one 50,000-gallon, two 28,750-gallon, and one 46,000-gallon tanks.  Aqua ammonia (20% Nitrogen), from railcars (i.e. Covered Process 4) and aqua ammonia blenders (i.e. Covered Process 5), is stored in the ASTs and then transferred to Commercial Tanker Trucks (i.e. Tanker Trucks) at two load-out stations (North and South).  The Tanker Trucks transport the aqua ammonia to the client location.



Trained Process Operators manage the aqua ammonia in the ASTs and perform the transfer of aqua ammonia from the stationary storage tanks to the Tanker Trucks in accordance with the PSM/RMPr Aqua Ammonia Storage and Handling Operating Procedures.  Trained HCC personnel perform the maintenance on this covered process in accordance with its PSM/RMPr Mechanical Integrity Procedures.  HCC is responsible for training its personnel in these Operating and Maintenance Procedures.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Helena Chemical Company (HCC) Central Ferry Facility Fertilizer Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained HCC staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. 



Covered Process 3 (i.e. Ammonium Polyphosphate Reacting) equipment associated with this covered process includes a 34,000-gallon anhydrous ammonia railcar, a phosphoric acid railcar, a water supply, railcar nipple adaptors, transfer hoses, emergency shutoff valves, and a mobile pipe reactor (MPR).  The MPR is owned and operated by an Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor (IFRC).   Ammonium Polyphosphate (i.e. 10-34-0) is a fertilizer that is manufactured by blending anhydrous ammonia with water and super-phosphoric acid in a ?stationary reactor? (i.e. Ammonium Polyphosphate Blending).  When manufacturing Ammonium Polyphosphate, the IFRC connects its MPR to (1) the anhydrous ammonia railcar, (2) water supply, and (3) the super-phosphoric acid railcar.  



The IFRC transfers the anhydrous ammonia from the railcar to its MPR in accordance with its PSM Operating Procedures.  The IFRC is responsible for the transfer of anhydrous ammonia when its equipment is connected to the stationary storage tank.  The IFRC is responsible for the training of its operators and maintenance of its equipment.  The Facility requires that the IFRC have in place and demonstrates compliance with its OSHA PSM for the MPR operations.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department.  Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



This Process Safety Management (PSM) and Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program document (PSM/RMPr) was prepared on behalf of Helena Chemical Company (HCC) pursuant to the requirements of the Clean Air Act ? 112(r) as codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) at 29 CFR ? 1910.119 and by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR ?68.  The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to operations at the Central Ferry Facility, Pomeroy, WA.  At this Facility, HCC engages in the formulation, distribution and sale of chemicals (i.e. retail) to customers, most of who use HCC's products to support agricultural operations.  



This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia from the Central Ferry Facility located approximately 23 miles northwest of Pomeroy, WA at 82 Central Ferry Road, Pomeroy, WA 99347.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Central Ferry Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Central Ferry Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release (even though a release is unlikely) will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



HCC is submitting this plan as a resubmission of all applicable sections of the PSM/RMP as it recently acquired this Facility from Nuchem.  All relevant sections for a Program 3 PSM/RMPr Facility have been addressed.  



FACILITY



The Operations at the Central Ferry Facility consists of agricultural chemical storage and handling, manufacturing, retail sale and distribution.  As related to the PSM/RMPr, the Central Ferry Facility stores and handles two covered chemicals (anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia) at quantities that exceed the threshold quantity established by EPA, and operates seven (7) covered processes that

involve storage, handling, and manufacturing of the covered chemicals.  The seven covered processes include:



o    Covered Process 1: Railcar Storage (Anhydrous Ammonia)

o    Covered Process 2: Railcar Storage (Aqua Ammonia)

o    Covered Process 3: Anhydrous Ammonia transfer to Tanker Truck

o    Covered Process 4: Aqua Ammonia Transfer to Storage Tanks

o    Covered Process 5: Aqua Ammonia Blending

o    Covered Process 6: Storage and Handling (Aqua Ammonia)

o    Covered Process 7: Ammonium Polyphosphate Blending



The Central Ferry Facility receives anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia (29% Nitrogen) by railcar.  The railcars are temporarily stored on the Facility spur until the material is transferred from the railcar to one of the other covered processes.  Railcars containing anhydrous ammonia are transferred to (1) Covered Process 3 for retail distribution to the client location; (2) Covered Process 5 for the manufacturing of aqua ammonia fertilizer; and (3) Covered process 7 for the manufacturing of ammonium polyphosphate (10-34-0) fertilizer.  Railcars containing aqua ammonia (29% Nitrogen), is mixed with water at Covered Process 4 while transferring the aqua ammonia (20% Nitrogen) to five (5) aboveground storage tanks (AST) for storage and handling (Covered Process 6).  The aqua that is blended at Covered Process 5 (Aqua Ammonia Blending) is transferred from the Blenders to the five (5) ASTs for storage and handling (Covered Process 6).  The aqua ammonia at Covered Process 6 (Storage and Handling) is transferred to Commercial Tanker Trucks for transportation to the client location.  HCC trains all of its Process Operators and Maintenance Personnel in the relevant operating and maintenance procedures provided in the PSM/RMPr.



It is important to note that the total quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored at the Facility is 3,302,072 lbs (assuming that 20 34,000-gallon railcars are filled to their administrative capacity), and the total aqua ammonia that can be sto

red at the Facility is 719,372 lbs (assuming that the nine 22,000-gallon railcars and five ASTs are filled to their administrative capacity).  



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for all seven (7) covered processes. The worst case scenario release assumed that all the contents in the largest single vessel were released.  For the anhydrous ammonia (i.e. representing Covered Processes 1, 3, 5, and 7), the worst case release was modeled as if a 34,000-gallon anhydrous ammonia railcar was punctured on the side at the ground level and the resulting release being a ground level horizontal jet at the maximum temperature.  For the aqua ammonia, two releases were modeled.  One worst case release scenario assumes that a 22,000-gallon aqua ammonia (29% Nitrogen) railcar failed and instantaneously spills the content into an area with no secondary containment resulting in a release being evaporation at the maximum temperature.  The other worst case release scenario assumes that the 50,000-gallon aqua ammonia (20% Nitrogen) AST fails within the secondary containment resulting in a contained release being evaporation at the maximum temperature.



Depending on the covered process, the alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario for anhydrous ammonia assumes a release of anhydrous ammonia due to (1) the failure to fully close a vapor valve on a railcar (Covered Process 1), and (2) rupture of a 3-inch transfer hose during a major loading or unloading operation associated with Covered Processes 3, 5, and 7.  Although these events are classified as an alternative scenario, even an accident of this type is unlikely to occur due to the safety equipment (excess flow devices, emergency shutoff valves, and internal safety valves on the tanker truck) and operating procedures that HCC uses to safeguard ammonia transfer operations.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario assumes a release of aqua ammonia (29

% Nitrogen) due to rupture of a 3-inch transfer hose during a major loading or unloading operation associated with Covered Processes 2 and 4, and a release of aqua ammonia (20% Nitrogen) due to a rupture of a 3-inch transfer hose during a major loading operation associated with Covered Process 6.  Although these events are classified as an alternative scenario, even an accident of this type is unlikely to occur due to the safety equipment (emergency shutoff valves and internal safety valves on the tanker truck) and operating procedures that HCC uses to safeguard ammonia transfer operations.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Central Ferry Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Central Ferry Manager is assisted by other trained HCC staff, as directed.  The Central Ferry Manager is responsible for ensuring that HCC Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Program 2 and 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



HCC's Central Ferry Facility is a non-responding facility. HCC has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at the Central Ferry Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by HCC at the Central Ferry Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r).  The RMP will be updated as the Central Ferry Facility adds, deletes, or chang

es processes.  The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Whitman County LEPC and local Fire Department.



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, and 6 of EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Central Ferry Facility.
